newsitem.title: GERMANY: BUNDS CLIMB FURTHER AFTER REPO ANNOUNCEMENT.
newsitem.headline: BUNDS CLIMB FURTHER AFTER REPO ANNOUNCEMENT.

text.p: Bund futures added to Monday's solid gains in early trade as traders showed their relief that the Bundesbank had decided against signalling a change in monetary policy at the repo tender.
In a widely expected, but closely watched move, the central bank set a tender for 14-day repos at an unchanged fixed rate of 3.0 percent.

As of last week, speculation had been rife the Bundesbank might use the repo to tighten monetary policy. Such talk had died down by Monday, however, as the recently weak mark posted a comeback against the dollar.
The Bundesbank move eased worries, at least for the moment, that interest rates are headed higher.

"The Bundesbank will not start the rate hike process without broad-based support on the council. The dollar needs to climb over 1.90 marks to win over doves on the council," said Joerg Kraemer, economist at Merrill Lynch.
The dollar stood at 1.8621 in morning trade on Tuesday.
The DTB Bund future fluctuated after the announcement, but soon began to climb, trading up 26 basis points at 102.18 at 0819 GMT.
Analysts said the market was further lifted by short-covering among speculators who had predicted a tightening of rates.
The gains, however, were most pronounced on the long-end of the curve with the short-end still seen burdened by worries that interest rates will climb in the not-too-distant future.
The spread between two- and 10-year maturities, for example, narrowed four basis points to 187 basis points.
Supporting the view the Bundesbank will keep a close eye on rates, the Federal Stastics office said inflation rose 1.9 percent year-on-year in July, its highest rate since June 1995.
The month-on-month rise in the consumer price index was 0.5 percent, the highest since January 1997.
With the Bundesbank out of the way, the focus is clearly on the U.S. where a slew of data is due in the next few days which could cripple Treasuries.
U.S. unit labour costs and productivity data are due at 1400 GMT on Tuesday and retail sales and producer price data are due Wednesday at 1230 GMT on Wednesday.
The spread between Treasuries and Bunds stood at 78 basis points on Tuesday morning.
